post.title: Testing
post.contents:
# Testing

> No matter how many tests succeed, we have always only run a finite number of tests compared to the infinity of tests the function would need to pass to establish its truth, so we cannot assign probabilities either. As a result, functions, just like explanations, have a probability of being true of 0.[^awoich3]

> When we do find an issue with an explanation or a function implementation, we want to avoid so-called "ad hoc fixes." An ad hoc fix is a fix whose introduction does not require much creativity and does not explain why the function failed in the first place.[^awoich3]

[^awoich3]: Hackethal, A Window on Intelligence: The Philosophy of People, Software, and Evolution â€“ and Its Implications, Chapter 3.
